comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: General Jose Santos Zelaya (white mustache), liberal former President (1893-1909) of Nicaragua, arrested in his bed in New York City by U. S. Marshall Henkel on a charge of murder, pursuant to an extradition treaty with the government of Nicaragua. Zelaya had been tried and convicted in absentia of murder, by the regime of his successors in Nicaragua. [Zelaya died in 1919, in New York City.] New York Times story of Zelaya's arrest, November 28, 1913: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=940DE7D61E3BE633A... An incomplete biography of Zelaya, on Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jos%c3%a9_Santos_Zelaya

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: LOC -- The photo shows us two men, Henkel [AND] Zelaya. Omitting the "and" leads to confusion and the erroneous supposition that you are labeling a single individual.

Wystan:

Thanks for the details on this image and for linking to the related photos. We will expand the record when we update.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: NYT story on November 13, 1913, reported that Zelaya had entered the U.S. at the port of New York, using an assumed name. He was accused of ordering the execution of two Americans who had fought against his regime in Nicaragua: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9402E0D71E3EE2...
